div.l: Grysil
Ther is ryght atte west syde of Italie
Downe at þᵉ rote of vessillus þᵉ olde
A lusty playne haboundant of vitayle
Wher many townse and towres þᵘ may beholde
That founden weren in tyme of faders olde
And many an othir deletabyl syght
And Slus þᵗat nobyl kuntre hyght
An Merkquys whylom was lord of þᵗat londe
As was his worthy auncestres hym beforne
And obeysaunt en redy to his hande
Weren al his liegis bothe lesse 7 more
Thus in delyte he lyued and hath done yore
Lovid and drede by fauoure of fortune
Both of his lordis and of his cōmmune
Ther wᵗith he was to speke of lynage
The gentillest borne of al Lumbardy
A fayre parsone stronge and yonge of age
And ful of honour and of curtasie
Dyscrete ynogh his countre for to guyde
Saue in some thyngꝭes he was to blame
And Walter was þᵉ yong lordys name
I blame hym thus þᵗat he considred not
In tyme comyng what myght hym betyde
But on his lust psent was al his thoght
As for to hauke and hunte on euỷer/re syde
Wele nygh al of honoure he lete slyde ??? waiting for folio image
Among this poure folk ther dwelte a man
Which that was holden pourest of hem alle
But heighe god som tyme senden kan
His grace in to a litel Oxes Stalle
Ianicula men of that Throop hym calle
A doghter hadde he fair ynogh to sighte
And Grisildis this yonge mayden highte
But for to speke of vertuous beautee
Thanne was she oon the faireste vnder the sonne
For poureliche yfostred vp was she
No likerous lust was thurgh hir herte yronne
Wel ofter of the welle than of the tonne
She drank and for she wolde vertu plese
She knew wel labour but noon ydel ese
Hit was hir lust and hir most ese
But thogh this mayde tendre were of age
Yet in the brest of hir virginitee
Ther was enclosed rype and sad corage
And in gret reuerence and charitee
Hir olde poure fader fostred she
A fewe sheep spynnynge on feld she kepte
She wolde noght been ydel til she slepte
And whan she homward cam she wolde brynge
Wortes or othere herbes tymes ofte
The whiche she shredde and seeth for his lyuynge
And made hir bed ful harde and no thyng softe
And ay she kepte hir fadres lyf on lofte
With euery obeysance and diligence
That child may doon to fadres reuerence
Vp on Grisilde this poure creature
Ful ofte sithe this Markys sette his eye
As he on huntyng rood per auenture
And whan it fil that he myghte hir espie
He noght wit wantowne lookyng of folye
Hise eyen caste on hir but in sad wyse
Vp on hir cheere he wolde hym ofte auyse
Comedynge in his herte her womanhede
And eke her vertu passyng any wyght
Of so yonge age as wel as dede
For though þᵉ peapyl haue none gret insighte
Her vertu he considerith ful ryght
Her beaute and disposid þᵗat he wolde
Her wedde if eủer/re he wedd shulde
The day of weddyng came but no wyght can
Tel what woman it shulde be
For whych mervauylle wondreth many a man
And sayde whan þey weren in prevyte
Wol he nat oure lorde leve his vanite
Wol he nat wedde alas þᵉ whyle
Why wol he hym selfe and vs begyle
But neủer/rethelesse þd???need superscript s here??? lorde let make
Of Jemmes set on golde ⁊and in asure
Broches ⁊and Ryngꝭes for Grysil sake
And of her clothyng toke he þᵉ mesure
Of a mayde lyke to her stature
Also of her ornementꝭes al
That to such a weddyng shuld befal
Þᵉ tyme of noon in þᵉ same daye
Approchid þᵗat this weddyng shulde be
And al þᵉ peapyl was set in aray
Bothe hal and chaumbr in theyre degre
Howsis of offices stuffed wᵗith grete plente
Ther men may se dayntes of vitayle
So rede he waxed and abassyng ⁊and qᵃkeyng
He stode vnnethes he sayd any worde moo
But only this lorde quod he my willyng
Is as your wyl not to gaynstand yoᵘur lykyng
I wol none þyng ye be myn lorde so dere
Ryght as you lyst goủer/rene þdˢ mater
Than wyl I do this qd Marcus softely
Þᵗat into þdˢ chaumbre I þᵘ ⁊and she
Haue a collaciou and wote þᵘ whye
For I wol aske her and her wyl be
To be my wyfe and reuled after me
And al this she shal be done in þy psens
I wol not speke oute of þyn audience
In this chambr whyle þay weren alone
Her tretys whych ye shal after here
Þᵉ peopyl cāmme in to þᵉ house wᵗith oute
And wondret hem in honeste mane
And tentyfly she kepte her fader dere
But vttely Grysil wondir myght
For neủer/re a fore sawe she suche a syght
No wondir were thogh she were astonyd
To se so grete a geste ??? come to þᵗat place
She was neủer/re to suche gestꝭes wunde
For whyche she lokyth wᵗith pale face
But shortly fro this mater to passe
Thise were þᵉ wordis þᵗat þᵉ lord sayde
To this benyngne verray feythful mayde
Grysilde he sayde I wil ye vndirstonde
It liketh vnto yoᵃ̉er/re ??? fader and me
þᵗat I you wedde and also to me stonde
As my suppose ye wil þᵗat ib ib it it ib it it be
But this demande I aske first q ???super d??? he
That it shal be done in hasti wyse
Wyl ye assent or ellys wyl te auyse
I saye be ye redy wᵗith good hert
To my luste þᵗat I frely maye
As me best lykyth done yow laugh or smerte
And ye neủer/re to gurge nyght ne daye
And eek when I say yes ye say not nay
Neyther be worde ne frowarde countennce ???ww w/ alpha above
Swere þd ???super s??? and here I swere oure alyaunce
Wondrynge vpon þd ???super s??? quakyng for drede
She sayde magne and vnworthy
Am I to þᵗat ye me bydde
But ryght as ye wol lord so wyl I
And swere þᵗat neủer/re willyngly
In worde ne dede I wol you disobey
For to be dede though me were loþe to dye
This is I nowe Grysyll myn owne qd he
And furth he goth wᵗith a sobir chere
Shud
Out at þᵉ dore and after þᵗat cam she
So sprad of her bounte the mdme of fame
That men and women as the yonge ⁊and olde
Come to Salus her to be holde
This Marquys weddid lowly nay but ryally
Wᵗith fortune and wᵗith honeste
In goddes peace lyuete wele honestly
Al hom and outward gᵃace Inough had he
And for he sawe vnder neth so lowe degre
Was ofte vertu hid the devyse hym he behylde
A prudent man and that sayne ful selde
Nought long tyme after this Gryseld
Was weddid she gate a dought̉er/re Ibore
Alle had he leủer/re haf borne a childe
Glad was this Marquys ⁊and his folke therfore
For though an mayde shyldeJiedeJiede shyldebefore
She may a knaf childe attayne
By lykhode sithen she is nat bareyne
Therfor it falleth tymys moo
When this shilde had souked but a throwe
This Markguys in hert thought so
To temper his wif her sadnes to know
That he ne myghte his hert throwe
This mvelous desyre his wyf to assay
Neủer/retheles he thought her to affray
He had assaued her Inough to fore
And fonde her euere good what nedith it ???Note Marginalia???
Her to tempte allwaie more ⁊and more
Though that some men pysith for an subtill wyt
But as for me I saie þᵗat eveyl it site
To assaie a woman when it is no nede
And put her in anguysshe ⁊and in drede
For which this Marquys though in this mane
A nyght alone where as she lay
Wᵗith sterne face and cruel cheere
And said to Grysil quod he that daie
That I you take of your pour araie
And put you in astateeeeee of heigh nobles
Yet ye haue not forgeten as I gesse
I saie Grysyld this psent Diginte
In whiche I haf put you as I trowe
Makith you not foryetful for to be
That I you take in poủer/ree astate ⁊and full lowe
For ne thinke you must yoᵘur self knowe
Takith hede to eủer/rey word that I saie
Ther is no wight þᵗat herith this but we tway
Ye woote wele yoᵘur self how ye cam heere
Into this house it is nat longe ago
And though ye be to me lief and dere
Vnto me gentle ye no thyng soo
The say to hem self it is grete shame ⁊and woo
Thise wordes hath þey spoken douteles
But I desire as I haue done before
To haue my lyfe in rest and peace
I may not in this cas be recchelees
I must done wᵗith þyn doughter þᵉ best
Not Iasas I wolde but as my gentles list
And yet god wote it is wel loth to me
But neủer/retheles wᵗith oute your̉er/re wittyng
I wol not don but þis I wyl quod he
Þᵗat ye to me assure as in this thynge
Sheweth nowe yoᵃ̉er/re pacience and worthynys
Þᵗat ye me behight in yoᵃ̉er/re vyllage
Þᵗat day þᵗat make was our̉er/re mariage
When she hard al this she was nat moved
Nanther in worde or chere ne contenᵃnce
For as it semed she was not a greved
She sayd lord al it lyeth in yoᵃ̉er/re plesaunce
Myn chylde ⁊and I wᵗith herty obeysaunce
Be youre al ⁊and ye may save and spyl
Your owne þing where þᵗat ye wyl
Ther may no thyng so god my soule saue
Lykyng to you þᵗat may displese me
Ne I desyryng no þyng to haue
Ne drede to lese ⁊and saue only ye
This wyl is in myn herte ⁊and eủer/re shal be
Nathing oflengthelengthe of tyme or deth may deface
Ne chaunge myn corage in other place
Glad was þᵉ Marquys for her answeryng
But yet hefayned as he were not soo
Al dry was his chere ⁊and his lokyng
When he oute shuld of þᵉ chaumbr goo
Shone after this a furlong weye or two
He playnly hath tolde al his entent
Vnto a man whych he to his wyf sente
A man of a ʆser/sirgeant was this good man
The whych þᵗat faithful he ofte founde had
In thyngꝭes grete and eke such folk wele can
Done execusion of þyngꝭes bad
The lorde knewe wel þᵗat he hym loued and drad
And when this lorde had tolde him his wyl
Into þᵉ chaumbir he stalkyth ful styl
Madame he sayde ye must for geue it me
Though I do þyngꝭes þᵉ whych I am constrayned
Ye ben so wys þᵗat wele knowe ye
That lordys behestys may not be fayned
That may be as wel wayled as complayned
But men must nedis to her behestys obeye
And so wyl I þ̉er/re is no more to saye
That chylde I am comaunded to take
And spake no more but þᵉ chylde he hent
Spituosly and gan a chere make
As he wolde haue it or he went
Grysil must al suffir ⁊and al consent
And as a babe she sat meke and stil
And leet þᵉ cruel ʆser/sirgeaunt haue his wyl
Suspecte was þᵉ name of þᵉ man
Suspect þᵉ tyme þᵗat he this began
For her dought̉er/re þᵗat she lowyd soo
She wende he shuld haue slayn it ryght thoo
But neủer/retheles she neythir wepte ne syqhed
Constraynyng her to þᵗat Marquysþᵉþᵉ Marquys lyked
But at þᵉ laste speke she began
So mekely to þᵉ ʆser/sirgeaunt prayed
So as he was a worthy man
That she myght kys her childe or þᵗat it deyde
And in her armes this lytel chylde she layde
Wᵗith sad face and gan þᵉ chylde to kysseblyssekysse blysse
And lullyd it and after gan it kesse
And thus she sayde in her benygne voice
Fare wele my childe I shal þᵉ neủer/re se
But sithen I haue marked þᵉ wᵗith þᵉ holy cross
Of myn fader blessid mot þᵘ be
That for vs died vppon þᵉ Rode tree
Thyne soule litel chylde I hym betake
For this nyght dye shalt þᵘ for myn sake
I trowe þᵗat to a Norys in this case
It had ben hard this ruth to se
Wel myghte a moder þan cry alasse
But neủer/rethelese so sad ⁊and stedfast was she
That she endured al adủer/resite
And to þᵉ ʆser/sirgeaunt mekely she sayd
Haue here ayen myn lytyl yong maide
And goith nowe and do myn lordys beheste
And one þyng wold I pᵃye you of youre gᵃce
That but my lorde forbade you at þᵉ laste
Bury this litel body in some place
That none beste it to race
But he no word to þᵗat purpose wolde say
But toke þᵉ childe and wente on his waye
This ʆser/sirgeaunt cōmme vnto þᵉ lorde ayen
And of Grysildis worde and of hir chere
He tolde hym poynt for poynt in shorte ⁊and playn
And hym psent wᵗith his dought̉er/re dere
Somwhat this lord hadde ruthe in his mane
But nev̉er/retheles his purpose helde he styl
As lordys done when þey wol haue her wyl
And bad þᵉ ʆser/sirgeaunt ful prevely
He shulde þᵉ chylde wynde ⁊and wrappe
Wᵗith alle þᵉ circumstaunce tendrely
And carye it in an cofir or in a lappe
But of payne his hede of to choppe
That no man shulde knowe of his entente
Ne whene he cōmme ne whedir he wente
But to Boleyne to his suster dere
That þan of pauy was Countesse
He shulde her take and shew her this mater
Besekyng her to done her besynes
This childe to foster in al goodnes
And whose childe it was he bad hir hyde
Fro eủer/rey wyght for aught þᵗat maye betyde
This ʆser/sirgeaunt goith ⁊and hath fulfillid this þyng
But to this Marquys nowe retorne we
For now goith he ful ofte faste ymagynyng
If he be his wyfe myghte se
That by her wordys yf þᵗat he
Wher chaunged but he couth neủer/ree fynde
But eủer/re mone lyke sad and kynde
As glad as busy as humble in ʆser/siruice
And eke in love as she was wonte to be
Was she to hym in eủer/rey man wyse
Ne of her an word spake she
Non accident for none adủer/resite
Was seyne in her ne in her doughter name
Named she for ernest ne for game
In this astate passed ben 4 yere
Er she wᵗith chylde was but as god wolde god woldeasas god wolde
A knaue chylde she be her lorde bare
Wele gᵃcous and fayre to beholde
And when folke to þᵉ fader tolde
Not only he but al þᵉ contre more
Was for this god to thanke ⁊and her
When it was two yere olde ⁊and fro þᵉ brest
Departed fro his moder on a daye
This Marquys caughte it on a oþ̉er/re liste
To tempte his wyffe yf þᵗat he maye
Un goodly was she temptyd in asaye
But wedded men knowe noo mesure
When þey fynde a pacient creature
Wyf quod this marquys ⁊and wyf ye haue hed or this
My peaple sekerly beren our̉er/re mariage
And namely sithen my son born is
Now it is wors þan eủer/re it was in oure age
The murmur sleith myn herte ⁊and my corage
For to myn Erys comyth þᵉ voyce so smerte
That it wel nyȝ distroy myn herte
For men sayn þus be I dede or gayn
Than shal þᵉ blode of Ianacle succede
And ben our̉er/re lorde for other haue we non
Such wordis sayne myn peapyl it is no drede
Wele might I of suche murmoᵘ take hede
For certenly I drede such countenᵘnce
Though þey not speken pleynly in myn audience
If I myght I wolde lyve in pease ⁊and I myghte
Right so I þynke I to ʆser/sirue hym pryvely
This warne I you þᵗat ye not sodenly
Oute of your self for no woo shulde ooutᵘraie
Beth pacient and þ̉er/reof I you pᵃye
I haue quod she said and eủer/re shal
I wol desire no þing certayne
But as you list nought grevyth me at al
Thogh þᵗat myn dought̉er/re and myn son be slayn
Al youre cōmmandement þ̉er/re is no mor̉er/re to sayn
I haue not had no parte of chyldren twayn
But firste sykenes woo ⁊and peyne
Ye beth oure lorde aske no rede of me
For as I lefte at home al myn lybleclothynglyble clothyng
When I come furst you to ryght quod she
Lefte I my wyl ⁊and al my libertee
And toke your̉er/re clothyng ??? wherfor I you pᵃye
Doo your wyl I wyl to you obeye
And certꝭes yf I had pscience
Your wil to knowe or ye yoᵃ list me tolde
But nowe I wote youᵃ lyste ⁊and what ye wolde
For wiste I my deeth myght wolde do you ease
Gladly wolde I it suffir you to do plese
Deth may make none compison
Vn to your love ⁊and when this lorde saye
The constance of his wyf he keste his hede down
And his two ⁊and wondred þᵗat she myght
In suche penannce suffir al this arraye
And forth he goth wᵗith drery countenᵃnce
But to his hert it was ful grete penannce
This egir ʆser/sirgeaunt in the same wyse
That he her daught̉er/re caught ryght so he
Or vors yf he couth wors devyse
Hath caught hir childe so ful was of beaute
And evir in one so pacient was she
That she non ther made of hevynese
But kyssith her son and aftir him blysse
Save þis she prayed if þᵗat he myght
Her litel son he wolde in erth graue
His tendir lymes delicate to sight
Fro foweles and bestꝭes to saue
But she none answer of hym myght haue
He went his weyes as he no þyng roughte
But vnto bologne tendirlye it broghte
This Markys wondryth eủer/re þᵉ lenger þᵉ more
Vppon her pacience and yf þᵗat he
Ne hadde knowen þᵉ soth before
That parfetly her chyldren loveth she
He wolde haue wend þᵗat of som subtylte
And of malice or of cruel corage
That she had suffred wᵗith sad vysage
But he knew þᵗat nexte hym selfe certayne
She loved her chyldren best in eủer/rey wyse
But nowe of women I wolle axe fayne
Yf thise assayes myght suffice
What couth a sturdy husband devyse
To preve his wyfe of stedfastnes
And he contynuyng in sturdynesse
But ther be folke of suche condicion
That when þey haue a certeyne takyn pᵃpose
They can not stynte of þeyre intencion
But as þey weren bounde tyl a stake
They wyl not of þeyre pᵃpose slake
Right as þis Marquys fully purposith
To tempte his wyf was fully dysposed
He wayted yef by worde or countenᵃnce
Yef she weren chaunged of corage
But nevir couth he fynde by experiance
She was eủer/re in herte ⁊and vysage
And eủer/remore feythful in age
The more trewe yf it were possibl
She was to hym in love and more pynyble
For which it semyth þus of hem two
Ther was but one wyl as her lorde lyste
The same luste was his al plesaunce also
And god be thankyd al fyl for þe beste
She shewyd wele for none worldely vnrest
A wyfe as of her selfe no thyng shulde
Wolden her enfecte but as her husbonde wolde
The sclaunder of Walter is wyde spradde
That of cruel herte wykkedly
For he a poure woman wedded had
Had murdred both his chyldren pʳuely
Wyche murmoᵃ was amonge hem softely
No wonder was for to þᵉ peaplys ere
Ther come no worde but þᵗat they murthrid were
For soth as for thes peapyl þᵗat byfore
Had lovid hym wele disclaunderyng of his name
Made þᵗat they hated hym þ̉er/refor
To be an murtherer it is an hateful name
But neủer/retheles for ernest ne for game
To tempte his wyfe was his his entent
He of his cruelte wolde not stynte
When his doughter xij yere was of age
He to tje courte of Rome in subtyl wyse
Enformed of his wil sent his message
Cōmmaundyng him suche bulles to brynge ⁊and devyse
As to his cruel counsel may suffice
How þᵗat þᵉ pope for his peapyles reste
